title: An associative array containing references to all variables which are currently defined in the global scope of the script. The variable names are the keys of the array.

inline_content.Text: An associative array containing references to all variables which are currently defined in the global scope of the script. The variable names are the keys of the array.

title: In the above example
$myLocal
c
is not displayed the second time because it is declared inside the
test()
c
function and then destroyed after the function is closed.

function and then destroyed after the function is closed.

title: To remedy this there are two options.

inline_content.Text: To remedy this there are two options.

title: The
global
c
keyword is a prefix on a variable that forces it to be part of the global scope.

inline_content.Text: keyword is a prefix on a variable that forces it to be part of the global scope.

title: Note that you cannot assign a value to a variable in the same statement as the global keyword. Hence, why I had to assign a value underneath. (It is possible if you remove new lines and spaces but I don’t think it is neat.
global $myLocal; $myLocal = "local"
c

inline_content.Text: Note that you cannot assign a value to a variable in the same statement as the global keyword. Hence, why I had to assign a value underneath. (It is possible if you remove new lines and spaces but I don’t think it is neat.

title: In this example I reassigned
$myLocal
c
the value of
$GLOBAL["myLocal"]
c
since I find it easier writing a variable name rather than the associative array.

inline_content.Text: since I find it easier writing a variable name rather than the associative array.

title: $_SERVER is an array containing information such as headers, paths, and script locations. The entries in this array are created by the web server. There is no guarantee that every web server will provide any of these; servers may omit some, or provide others not listed here. That said, a large number of these variables are accounted for in the CGI/1.1 specification, so you should be able to expect those.

inline_content.Text: $_SERVER is an array containing information such as headers, paths, and script locations. The entries in this array are created by the web server. There is no guarantee that every web server will provide any of these; servers may omit some, or provide others not listed here. That said, a large number of these variables are accounted for in the CGI/1.1 specification, so you should be able to expect those.

of the documentation.

title: For all explanations below, assume the URL is http://www.example.com/index.php

inline_content.Text: For all explanations below, assume the URL is http://www.example.com/index.php

title: HTTP_USER_AGENT
c
- Contents of the user agent. This is a string which contains all the information about the client’s browser, including operating system.

inline_content.Text: - Contents of the user agent. This is a string which contains all the information about the client’s browser, including operating system.

title: HTTP_COOKIE
c
- All cookies in a concatenated string, with a semi-colon delimiter.

inline_content.Text: - All cookies in a concatenated string, with a semi-colon delimiter.

title: SERVER_ADDR
c
- The IP address of the server, of which the current script is running.

inline_content.Text: - The IP address of the server, of which the current script is running.

title: PHP_SELF
c
- The file name of the currently executed script, relative to document root.

inline_content.Text: - The file name of the currently executed script, relative to document root.

title: REQUEST_TIME_FLOAT
c
- The timestamp of the start of the request, with microsecond precision. Available since PHP 5.4.0.

inline_content.Text: - The timestamp of the start of the request, with microsecond precision. Available since PHP 5.4.0.

title: REQUEST_TIME
c
- The timestamp of the start of the request. Available since PHP 5.1.0.

inline_content.Text: - The timestamp of the start of the request. Available since PHP 5.1.0.

title: An associative array of variables passed to the current script via the URL parameters.

inline_content.Text: An associative array of variables passed to the current script via the URL parameters.

title: $_GET
c
is an array that contains all the URL parameters; these are the whatever is after the ? in the URL.

inline_content.Text: is an array that contains all the URL parameters; these are the whatever is after the ? in the URL.

title: Using http://www.example.com/index.php?myVar=myVal as an example. This information from this URL can be obtained by accessing in this format
$_GET["myVar"]
c
and the result of this will be
myVal
c

&
c
) character.

inline_content.Text: It is possible to send multiple variables through the URL by separating them with an ampersand (

title: It is very important not to send any sensitive information via the URL as it will stay in history of the computer and will be visible to anyone that can access that browser.

inline_content.Text: It is very important not to send any sensitive information via the URL as it will stay in history of the computer and will be visible to anyone that can access that browser.

title: An associative array of variables passed to the current script via the HTTP POST method when using application/x-www-form-urlencoded or multipart/form-data as the HTTP Content-Type in the request.

inline_content.Text: An associative array of variables passed to the current script via the HTTP POST method when using application/x-www-form-urlencoded or multipart/form-data as the HTTP Content-Type in the request.

title: Very similar to
$_GET
c
in that data is sent from one place to another.

inline_content.Text: in that data is sent from one place to another.

title: I’ll start by going straight into an example. (I have omitted the action attribute as this will send the information to the page that the form is in).

inline_content.Text: I’ll start by going straight into an example. (I have omitted the action attribute as this will send the information to the page that the form is in).

title:
<form method="POST">
    <input type="text" name="myVar" value="myVal" />
    <input type="submit" name="submit" value="Submit" />
</form>

content_resolved.code:
<form method="POST">
    <input type="text" name="myVar" value="myVal" />
    <input type="submit" name="submit" value="Submit" />
</form>

title: Above is a basic form for which data can be sent. In an real environment the
value
c
attribute would not be set meaning the form would be blank. This would then send whatever information is entered by the user.

inline_content.Text: Above is a basic form for which data can be sent. In an real environment the
attribute would not be set meaning the form would be blank. This would then send whatever information is entered by the user.

title: Sending data via POST is also not secure. Using HTTPS will ensure that data is kept more secure.

inline_content.Text: Sending data via POST is also not secure. Using HTTPS will ensure that data is kept more secure.

title: An associative array of items uploaded to the current script via the HTTP POST method. The structure of this array is outlined in the POST method uploads section.

inline_content.Text: An associative array of items uploaded to the current script via the HTTP POST method. The structure of this array is outlined in the POST method uploads section.

title: Let’s start with a basic form.

inline_content.Text: Let’s start with a basic form.

title:
<form method="POST" enctype="multipart/form-data">
    <input type="file" name="myVar" />
    <input type="submit" name="Submit" />
</form>

content_resolved.code:
<form method="POST" enctype="multipart/form-data">
    <input type="file" name="myVar" />
    <input type="submit" name="Submit" />
</form>

title: Note that I omitted the
action
c
attribute (again!). Also, I added
enctype="multipart/form-data"
c
, this is important to any form that will be dealing with file uploads.

inline_content.Text: , this is important to any form that will be dealing with file uploads.

title: This is used to upload one file. Sometimes you may wish to upload more than one file. An attribute exists for that, it’s called
multiple
c

inline_content.Text: This is used to upload one file. Sometimes you may wish to upload more than one file. An attribute exists for that, it’s called

anything
i
I’m sorry
a
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=szrsfeyLzyg

inline_content.Text: There’s an attribute for just about

title: Below is an example of a form submitting multiple files.

inline_content.Text: Below is an example of a form submitting multiple files.

title:
<form method="POST" enctype="multipart/form-data">
    <input type="file" name="myVar[]" multiple="multiple" />
    <input type="submit" name="Submit" />
</form>

content_resolved.code:
<form method="POST" enctype="multipart/form-data">
    <input type="file" name="myVar[]" multiple="multiple" />
    <input type="submit" name="Submit" />
</form>

title: Note the changes made here; there are only a few.

inline_content.Text: Note the changes made here; there are only a few.

title: The
input
c

name has square brackets. This is because it is now an array of files and so we are telling the form to make an array of the files selected. Omitting the square brackets will result in the latter most file being set to
$_FILES["myVar"]
c

inline_content.Text: name has square brackets. This is because it is now an array of files and so we are telling the form to make an array of the files selected. Omitting the square brackets will result in the latter most file being set to

title: The
multiple="multiple"
c
attribute. This just tells the browser that users can select more than one file.

inline_content.Text: attribute. This just tells the browser that users can select more than one file.

documentation
a

title: The first process is checking if there are any files, and if so, set the total number of them to
$total
c

inline_content.Text: The first process is checking if there are any files, and if so, set the total number of them to

title: Using the for loop allows an iteration of the
$_FILES
c
array and accessing each item one at a time. If that file doesn’t encounter a problem then the if statement is true and the code from the single file upload is run.

inline_content.Text: Using the for loop allows an iteration of the
array and accessing each item one at a time. If that file doesn’t encounter a problem then the if statement is true and the code from the single file upload is run.

title: If an problem is encountered the switch block is executed and an error is presented in accordance with the error for that particular upload.

inline_content.Text: If an problem is encountered the switch block is executed and an error is presented in accordance with the error for that particular upload.

title: An associative array of variables passed to the current script via HTTP Cookies.

inline_content.Text: An associative array of variables passed to the current script via HTTP Cookies.

title: Cookies are variables that contain data and are stored on the client’s computer.

inline_content.Text: Cookies are variables that contain data and are stored on the client’s computer.

title: Unlike the aforementioned superglobals, cookies must be created with a function (and not be assigning a value). The convention is below.

inline_content.Text: Unlike the aforementioned superglobals, cookies must be created with a function (and not be assigning a value). The convention is below.

title: In this example a name is specified for the cookie (in this example it is “myVar”), a value is given (in this example it is “myVal”, but a variable can be passed to assign its value to the cookie), and then an expiration time is given (in this example it is one hour since 3600 seconds is a minute).

inline_content.Text: In this example a name is specified for the cookie (in this example it is “myVar”), a value is given (in this example it is “myVal”, but a variable can be passed to assign its value to the cookie), and then an expiration time is given (in this example it is one hour since 3600 seconds is a minute).

title: Despite the convention for creating a cookie being different, it is accessed in the same way as the others.

inline_content.Text: Despite the convention for creating a cookie being different, it is accessed in the same way as the others.

title: To destroy a cookie,
setcookie
c
must be called again, but the expiration time is set to
any
i
time in the past. See below.

inline_content.Text: must be called again, but the expiration time is set to
time in the past. See below.

title: This will unset the cookies and remove it from the clients computer.

inline_content.Text: This will unset the cookies and remove it from the clients computer.

title: An associative array containing session variables available to the current script. See the Session functions documentation for more information on how this is used.

inline_content.Text: An associative array containing session variables available to the current script. See the Session functions documentation for more information on how this is used.

title: Sessions are much like cookies except they are server side.

inline_content.Text: Sessions are much like cookies except they are server side.

title: To use sessions you must include
session_start()
c
at the top of your scripts to allow sessions to be utilised.

inline_content.Text: To use sessions you must include
at the top of your scripts to allow sessions to be utilised.

title: Setting a session variable is the same as setting any other variable. See example below.

inline_content.Text: Setting a session variable is the same as setting any other variable. See example below.

title: When starting a session a random ID is set as a cookie and called “PHPSESSID” and will contain the session ID for that current session. This can be accessed by calling the
session_id()
c
function.

inline_content.Text: When starting a session a random ID is set as a cookie and called “PHPSESSID” and will contain the session ID for that current session. This can be accessed by calling the

title: It is possible to destroy session variables using the
unset
c
function (such that
unset($_SESSION["myVar"])
c
would destroy that variable).

inline_content.Text: It is possible to destroy session variables using the

title: The alternative is to call
session_destory()
c
. This will destroy the entire session meaning that
all
b
session variables will no longer exist.

inline_content.Text: . This will destroy the entire session meaning that
session variables will no longer exist.

title: An associative array that by default contains the contents of $_GET, $_POST and $_COOKIE.

inline_content.Text: An associative array that by default contains the contents of $_GET, $_POST and $_COOKIE.

title: As the PHP documentation states, this is just a collation of
$_GET
c
$_POST
c
, and
$_COOKIE
c
all in one variable.

inline_content.Text: As the PHP documentation states, this is just a collation of

title: Since it is possible for all three of those arrays to have an index with the same name, there is a setting in the
php.ini
c
file called
request_order
c
which can specify which of the three has precedence.

inline_content.Text: Since it is possible for all three of those arrays to have an index with the same name, there is a setting in the
which can specify which of the three has precedence.

title: For instance, if it was set to
"GPC"
c
, then the value of
$_COOKIE
c
will be used, as it is read from left to right meaning the
$_REQUEST
c
will set its value to
$_GET
c
, then
$_POST
c
, and then
$_COOKIE
c
and since
$_COOKIE
c
is last that is the value that is in
$_REQUEST
c

inline_content.Text: For instance, if it was set to
will be used, as it is read from left to right meaning the
is last that is the value that is in

title: An associative array of variables passed to the current script via the environment method.

inline_content.Text: An associative array of variables passed to the current script via the environment method.

title: These variables are imported into PHP’s global namespace from the environment under which the PHP parser is running. Many are provided by the shell under which PHP is running and different systems are likely running different kinds of shells, a definitive list is impossible. Please see your shell’s documentation for a list of defined environment variables.

inline_content.Text: These variables are imported into PHP’s global namespace from the environment under which the PHP parser is running. Many are provided by the shell under which PHP is running and different systems are likely running different kinds of shells, a definitive list is impossible. Please see your shell’s documentation for a list of defined environment variables.

title: Other environment variables include the CGI variables, placed there regardless of whether PHP is running as a server module or CGI processor.

inline_content.Text: Other environment variables include the CGI variables, placed there regardless of whether PHP is running as a server module or CGI processor.

title: Anything stored within
$_ENV
c
is from the environment from which PHP is running in.

inline_content.Text: is from the environment from which PHP is running in.
